I whole heartedly agree with u/angbhb333 ‘s comment but I’d like to add some more. Specifically around the codependency, blaming herself for everything and the Charlie thing.

To start off with, Bella’s not just assuming Charlie doesn’t like shopping. He’s her dad and despite their distant relationship, there are things people pick up on about their parents. Bella understands that her father is a quiet, protective but stereotypically masculine person. He doesn’t like shopping, he doesn’t like cooking and he’s not a fan of things that might be perceived as unnecessary. He’s a basic guy who (I would imagine) would be quite happy living in a cabin in the woods, away from everyone. Yes, this is how SM wrote him and yes, it’s a stereotype but it’s not how Bella as the protagonist is perceiving it. And there are plenty of other characters who don’t fall into stereotypes.

The other thing that is important to remember is that Bella basically grew up neglected. It’s not explicitly stated in the original saga and we see more of that in MS but at the end of the day, Renee is unreliable and frankly, IMO, she comes off as more interested in being Bella’s friend than her parent. So, by extension, as we saw in MS (and sometimes in Twilight), Bella was forced into a parenting role from a young age. 

Now, in more recent years, this kind of upbringing has been acknowledged as a form of abuse - parentification and neglect. This kind of upbringing forces kids into the selfless role and plants the seeds of codependency. And on top of that, can be a factor in anxiety and depression. A big factor in anxiety is believing you are at fault or worrying about how you’ve done something wrong. 

Now whether or not SM deliberately factored all of that into her writing, we’ll never really know. Although we do know from MS that she presents it so Edward is able to deduce a not fantastic home life from how caring Bella is. But at the end of the day, these flaws, traits and factors in her character are what made her relatable to many. I know that I, coming from an abusive household, saddled with parentification and now dealing with codependency and anxiety, definitely was able to connect *because* of those traits.

I am European, too, and we would definitely go shopping, even when we didn't have "above average" income - we would at least go to thrift shops. We would go to the mall every lunch break. Yes, we wouldn't spend huge amounts of money (although I knew people who would overspend their budget), but I doubt poor people in the US would either (some, of course, not everyone - credit card culture plays into that). I don't think there is such a huge difference, I think it's mostly what we see in films and tv shows, at least from what I've gathered from some US American friends/acquaintances. Definitely not unusual for girls to be expected to "like shopping" and lower-income families do think it's a hobby. I really, really don't think it's nowadays a US-specific stereotype. If you are talking about spending hundredths of dollars multiple times per week then sure, but that's not "outside the US", that's kind of unusual for anyone who doesn't have lots of money.  
As with cars, sure, not everyone has a car, I don't for one, but I know lots of people in their early twenties - from various economical backgrounds - who do own a car. Not new ones, sure, but they do have a car. It definitely varies though.  


Honestly, having a house when you're poor is a bit more US-typical to me - we don't have many cardboard houses here so most low-income people live in flats.

Even in the director’s notebook, she mentions how she specifically wanted Kristen to do the kissing scene on the bed because she saw her do it in another movie and wanted that vibe. But in doing so, she jumbled up other scenes to make that happen and then we ended up with the meme that is Bella saying Edward’s a vampire. It was totally inorganic compared to the car scene in the book. 

I also feels like they sucked all the wittiness out of Bella to accomodate the more dark and brooding vision Hardwicke had. She was sarcastic and witty and funny in the books but we end up with a flat Bella (who only becomes more animated in the following movies) and Kristen Stewart gets labelled as emotionless when that’s what was pretty much asked of her. 

Don’t get me wrong, I love the movie, I love that it started the series and I know that there was a limited budget but damn there are some things in the movie that are (as you mentioned) so bad that it’s funny.
